name: 3,5-di-tert-butyl-o-benzoquinone
Reason: The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. tert-Butyl groups are bulky and usually increase the melting point significantly because they provide steric hindrance which makes the molecular packing in the solid state more ordered, and thus, more energy is required to disrupt the crystal lattice. We can estimate each tert-butyl group to add approximately +20 degrees Celsius to the melting point due to increased van der Waals interactions and ordered packing. There are two tert-butyl groups substituting the benzene ring, so the cumulative increase is +40 degrees Celsius. The quinone structure (o-benzoquinone core) has a high degree of conjugation and rigidity which often increases the melting point when compared to benzene due to the stronger intermolecular forces, such as dipole-dipole interactions because of the polar carbonyl groups. This could add an additional +30 degrees Celsius to the melting point. Considering all these modifications from the basic benzene unit: 5.5 (benzene) + 40 (two tert-butyl groups) + 30 (quinone structure), we arrive at our prediction.

name: 3,5-di-tert-butyl-o-benzoquinone
Reason: The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. Adding sterically bulky tert-butyl groups typically increases the melting point due to enhanced van der Waals interactions and reduced molecular mobility in the solid state; each tert-butyl may contribute around +30 degrees Celsius. The presence of the quinone structure introduces polar carbonyl groups that also raise the melting point due to stronger dipole-dipole interactions and increased molecular rigidity, this can contribute around +50 degrees Celsius due to the conjugation and the rigidity of the structure. Since there are two tert-butyl groups, the adjustment for tert-butyl groups is doubled. Summing these contributions: 5.5 (benzene) + 60 (two tert-butyl groups) + 50 (quinone structure), we get a total predicted increase.
